article.headline: Vanderbilt 79, Arkansas 65
article.story: NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) -- Mario Moore finally looked like the player the Vanderbilt Commodores need if they are to make another run in the NCAA tournament. Moore scored 20 points and had 13 assists, one off the school record, as Vanderbilt (16-10, 6-6 Southeastern Conference) remained in contention for a tournament berth with a 79-65 victory over Arkansas (17-9, 5-8) on Saturday night. He has struggled at times this season, scoring less than 10 points in four of his last six SEC games. But he returned to form, hitting all 10 of his free throws and two second-half 3-pointers. The Commodores have now won five of their last seven games. "Mario brings a lot of energy to the court," said Shan Foster, who added a season-high 25 points and hit five 3-pointers. "We feed off him. When he's as enthusiastic as he was tonight, the sky's the limit for us." Jason Holwerda scored 10 points for Vanderbilt, but it was Moore who kept the streaky Commodores ahead. "Moore was just outstanding," Arkansas coach Stan Heath said. "I know he's been up and down, but tonight he was the best player on the court." If the Commodores are to return to the NCAA Tournament for the second straight year, it will need better play from Moore, who scored 26 points in the team's first-round win last year against Western Michigan. Vanderbilt connected on 12 of 27 3-point attempts against the SEC's best perimeter defense. "If we slow the game down, we can get what we want," Foster said. Leading 55-51, Vanderbilt went on a 19-7 run to take a 74-58 lead with two minutes to play. A questionable intentional foul call on Arkansas' Rashard Sullivan sparked the spurt. Moore hit two free throws after the foul and Foster hit a 3-pointer from the corner to complete a five-point possession. Dawid Przybyszewski added a pair of 3-pointers in the decisive run. "(The intentional foul) was a big play," Vanderbilt coach Kevin Stallings said. "I don't want to say it was the game because we had control of the game. I don't think we were in danger of them taking control of the game." Ronnie Brewer led Arkansas with 20 points and five assists, while Jonathon Mordica and Olu Famutimi scored 10 points. Arkansas still has NCAA tournament hopes, but has only beaten Mississippi and Missouri on the road. Arkansas is 4-23 on the road under coach Heath. "This game was pivotal for both teams," Heath said. "We really needed this game tonight. In the second half, Vanderbilt really cranked it up a notch."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
